title: Leong Utek
text:
I am a Psychology PhD candidate at the National University of Singapore, advised by Associate Professor Ryan Hong.
Broadly, I am interested in the study of how personality and individual differences influence physical and mental health outcomes. For my PhD research, I am currently investigating the relationships between cognitive vulnerabilities and internalizing psychopathology using psychological network modelling. During my free time, I enjoy tending to my tropical houseplants, listening to melodic hardcore, and taking walks with my beautiful wife.
If you would like to contact me, please drop me an email at utek@outlook.com.

title: Leong Utek’s CV
text:
Leong Utek
Broadly, I am interested in advancing healthcare research in Singapore through the study of individual differences. I am currently researching the cognitive-affective vulnerabilities to internalising psychopathology from a network perspective. My specific research interests include:

Hierarchical and network approaches to psychopathology
History of psychology/psychiatry
Individual differences in treatment adherence and its associated processes

To supplement my training as a psychological researcher, I have also been pursuing collaboration with researchers from the NUS Saw Swee Hock School of Public Health and Duke-NUS Medical School to broaden my exposure to research in the health domain.

Personality and Psychopathology Lab, National University of Singapore
N/A

Coordinated a research project investigating proximal cognitive vulnerabilities and their association with internalising symptoms of psychopathology.



Associate Clinical Research Coordinator
Department of Psychology, Singapore General Hospital
N/A
2021 - 2021

Coordinated a collaborative project between the Department of Psychology and Department of Podiatry that I proposed to investigate the psychological determinants of lower-limb orthotic device adherence. This research study was executed to fulfil the thesis requirement of my undergraduate degree.
Collaborated with a team of researchers on the development and validation of a novel mindfulness questionnaire designed for the Singaporean context.
Assisted in the screening (via the Mini-Mental State Examination) and recruitment of stroke survivors and their caregivers for stroke rehabilitation research projects.



Clinical Research Intern
Department of Psychology, Singapore General Hospital
N/A
2020 - 2019

Generated a mindfulness item pool designed for the Singaporean context; conducted several cognitive interviews to ensure the suitability and intelligibility of these items.
Conducted literature reviews on topics such as second victim syndrome, stroke intervention adherence, and questionnaire construction.
Assisted in other research projects assessing the efficacy of mindfulness-based group interventions in clinical populations (e.g. stroke, sleep difficulties).



Student Researcher
NTU Touch Lab, Nanyang Technological University
N/A
2019 - 2018

Supervised by Associate Professor Ryo Kitada and Dr Achille Pasqualotto
Conducted independent research to examine the multisensory relationships between plesantness and softness.

title: Blog
text:
Feeling like a real scientist





Mixed feelings during an exciting time





Nov 28, 2023






No matching items

title: Feeling like a real scientist
text:
With the year coming to a close, I thought it would be a good time to start blogging so that I can document some thoughts in slightly longer-form.

It has been an eventful year. I must say that I am extremely proud of all that I have achieved professionally this year! I published my first first author paper this May, passed my qualifying exams in August, got invited to review my very first paper last month, and got cited for the first time (lol). All in all a very exciting time.
Yet… I can’t help but feel sad that it took a string of achievements for me to finally feel like a bona fide scientist. Have I begun the downward spiral of measuring my worth as a researcher by the number of papers and citations I have?
Maybe this is the product of my pragmatism fuelled Singaporean upbringing … or the scientific milieu … or my undying need to prove something to myself. It doesn’t matter. What matters is that I start reminding myself that I am a scientist because I have been trained to think critically and problem solve and not because I’ve written some musty papers.
